document.title: STRANDS AND STANDARDS EARLY CHILDHOOD EDUCATION 3

295096521E0C475B8CF569F168AF91FC.description: Follow up. Evaluate how the plan worked

E700E4AFE85143DCB503BFE0357155B2.description: Work out ways of putting the plan into action.

C42EEAE8EABA43D990C647A2F302C7AE.description: Examine each idea for its merits or drawbacks. Decide which idea to try.

4965BCEADF5A4FEB9AFE34931272BD6E.description: Generate possible solutions as a group.

B35E71237DAB44F7861FDD25BF53E112.description: Invite children to participate in fixing the problem.

2C17CB56C43A41088045F1E9CB5022D9.description: Identify the problem and define it as a shared problem.

8E79DF09F36C4E349110DD4165B4EF9B.description: Active Intervention: Steps in Teaching Conflict Resolution

45682C0C6A7A4AB7880B8BBED437F110.description:
Physical Intervention: Physically stop children when they are hurting each other. Then focus on actively
resolving the conflict at hand.

D73156E236B6416F9193003F916177B0.description:
Passive Intervention: Giving children time to work through their own problems. If a situation does not
escalate to destructive or aggressive behavior, simply observe as the children seek a solution, or be
present to serve as a gentle reminder to use words instead of action. Trust children to ‘figure it out’
and help as needed.

958DA8E333E449C8B771930D8CB14713.description: Facilitate and encourage the development of independent problem solving.

609EB64F2A96439E82693F54EAB32BFF.description: Problem solving: A tool to express feelings without blaming or judging.

54430E23D5BE4B0FAE20218D34A6CCAF.description: Assertiveness: respectfully and clearly teach others how to treat us.

8452DC9CB0FC462BB77D4642F868CA7B.description: Emotional intelligence: become more comfortable with labeling their emotions and communicating them to others.

58C9343ABA55424698585117D88FD4BA.description: Identify the reasons to teach and use i-messages in an early childhood setting.

187D8E3E8FD343349DF4C6BD10B916C2.description:
Ex: “I feel worried when you climb up the slide because you might get hurt next time please use the
ladder.”

C4551192887F470C957050191443BF41.description: An i-message should follow this form “I feel when because , next time please .”

9BB41D260E7E409D86E7AB2377FCA1FF.description: I-messages: A specific description of behavior how it affects you, and your feelings about it.

4EF5BA3A17E24D4EB60F6FD6C135E715.description: Identify i-messages in the use of positive guidance strategies

9967C146235C4DEE97CB78E12775CCD9.description:
Students will review guidance strategies in Early Childhood Education 1 Strand 3 & 4.
Examine positive guidance strategies I-messages and problem solving.

F120463025754BC2BE14021D9C9E9202.description: Quiet- English Language Arts and technology

FBC300AB57774ACC94169C965487C256.description:
Containers and shelves are child sized and labeled with words and pictures to support
independence and language skills.

22ACAF73043D4354BCAD08572C0BD624.description:
The space should be inclusive (multicultural, non-sexist, differing abilities) through books, pictures and
learning materials

E5EDC06A5FBF425298A19C36B76BCA1B.description: Children should have ownership in the space (ie: children’s artwork displayed at their eye level)

973CE2E2F4B3434DBB65AE80EEBDE57A.description: Space should be welcoming, pleasing to the eye and safe

2484C996417F4AC4813E73EC9B74AEC4.description: Centers are defined and include a quiet/calming space where a child can be alone

60030A4E26C64726BB969BE2A58E3A42.description: Children will be inclined to act appropriately if the space is orderly and organized with a place for everything

74419E05D2AB4F63B3B3B6C298074EC0.description: Everything in your space, including furniture, materials and supplies set the tone for the class

CA8F56277DD74702AF872F8C10CDB042.description: Review and implement a developmentally appropriate environment and curriculum

7B6804F497A1426F82C3322F237A68D5.description: Students will evaluate and model developmentally appropriate practices with children

EE82D4F115414D8899A92548C7B8DA35.description: Supervise sleeping infants by having them sleep in a location where you can see and hear them or by doing an in-person observation at least once every 15 minutes.

E7F8B7DC5B704D839FDBF868560E0D40.description: Avoid letting infants get too hot when they are sleeping. Infants are too hot when you see them sweating or have damp hair, flushed cheeks, heat rash, or rapid breathing.

B3F4AC7D70E04A7C9FD54776AB7531DE.description: Supervise sleeping infants by having them sleep in a location where you can see and hear them or by doing an in-person observation at least once every 15 minutes covering them with blankets.

3EA25B4671544EF0A090E96CBD5C44B8.description: Avoid letting infants get too hot when they are sleeping. Signs of overheating include sweating, damp hair, flushed cheeks, heat rash, or rapid breathing.

84202677B675488B8D1F9EE25C570D9B.description: Dress infants in sleep clothing, such as sleepers and sleep sacks, instead using blankets

E73C4E2193A740DFB11A1619EFF11228.description: Sleep infants in equipment designed for sleep, such as cribs or bassinets. Car seats, strollers, and swings should be avoided for sleeping.

E51BBDA370874E57BC72CCFBF45BF9AF.description: No toys, pillows, stuffed animals, bumper pads, or wedges in the crib or bassinet.

BD8A229170FE4A53B9CFB6854BFB498F.description: Always place infants on their backs for sleeping.

B2160D7C1416495386C4C6EE22D7D559.description: Use safe sleep practices to reduce the risk of SIDS:

D6FC531F61E64EB1944E02529EAF7F99.description: SIDS is the sudden, unexplained death of an apparently healthy child in their sleep (often under 1 year old)

30DA58AB8FE54B2394FBF1EF042E9D94.description: Describe sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) and prevention strategies.

30DC53B180354446B927F0C20EFAE3AF.description: At least one of every four babies who experience AHT dies from this form of child abuse.

C844EAE89FC64EEC9392B17D386E340E.description: If your coping threshold (how much a person can take of something) for crying is reached and there is no one around to relieve you by taking the baby, put the crying baby down in its crib, close the door, and go do something to relieve the stress (i.e. dance to loud music, vacuum, watch TV, etc.) Checking on the baby every 5-10 minutes.

61CFAE8E3F5D4B45A62ECA3FD7A07539.description: Techniques for soothing an infant: Touch, Motion, Sound.

117AA8EE5A154C8C930460A431A7BF01.description: Examine ways to cope with crying.

DD4039112FBE4B4D8C5794A65BC1F43D.description: Abusive head trauma is preventable by responding to infant crying appropriately.

7B584BDE5E2146A0AA4CDC0C91344F0D.description:
AHT often happens when a parent or caregiver becomes angry or frustrated because of a child’s
crying.

2E98C761D0A64438A88D237602F435C8.description: The resulting injury can cause bleeding around the brain or on the inside back layer of the eyes.

7CF5EDB3686E4B8CA4BDA68B714F3B98.description: It is caused by violent shaking and/or with blunt impact.

A16954767D1844A086E96D41613D7681.description:
Abusive head trauma (AHT), including shaken baby syndrome, is a severe form of child abuse that
results in brain injury.

B924F9255C6A48529D6F9114AE956CBC.description: Describe causes, prevention, and consequences for infant Abusive Head Trauma(AHT).

F22448082BEE466F9FF486B5C5FFD4DB.description: Interactions with the children shall not include: restraining a child’s movement by binding, tying, or any other form of restraint that exceeds gentle, passive restraint

84269158EE294DB69B002E3084B46FB2.description: Individuals who interact with the children shall guide children’s behavior by using positive reinforcement, redirection and by setting clear limits that promote children’s ability to become selfdisciplined Caregivers shall use gentle, passive restraint with children only when it is needed to stop children from injuring themselves or others, or from destroying property

640E3C431A4E4FC889826EDE786F05B1.description: Inform parents, children and those who interact with the children of the center’s behavioral expectations and how any misbehavior will be handled

E15C6D71279D4EF58C74183FDFAD24AC.description: neglect, or dependency to immediately notify the nearest office of Child and Family Services, a peace officer, or a law enforcement agency.

61284B4181494C5EABDAD8A7A2A05F1A.description: Utah law requires any person who has reason to believe that a child has been subjected to abuse,

9A88B53402F049E1BF51CB6C84BCE566.description: Provider shall ensure that no child is subjected to physical, emotional, or sexual abuse while in care.

2026C0B4F9D745D0AE2E6E8A51F13C7E.description: Identify the signs of child abuse

7B6D58ED25714C4494FB7C25D9F1655B.description: Identify signs of child abuse, abusive head trauma, and sudden infant death syndrome.

CFEF1906E7204E088AAAD31ED5291B06.description: Providers should be aware of food allergies and sensitivities and ensure that children are not served the food or drink of which they are allergic/sensitive

2BD84E7F9ED4490ABB1499594155C43A.description: Each child age 2 years and older is offered a meal or snack at least once every 3 hours

B6981AE2901940EB967A995545ED3FDF.description: Gloves should be worn during diapering/toileting practices, first-aid and when handling food

03B2AD6D10CC4BD785CC55A81CBB4756.description: A child who is ill with an infectious disease may not be cared for at the center except when the child shows signs of illness after arriving at the center

4569992D7D2D484DBC1C81862361740E.description: After cleaning up or taking out garbage

0300C77B153342DA89F2116D12932D79.description: When coming in from outdoors or arriving to work

921A4BA015CA48C48236E4CCC227582C.description: After contact with a body fluid

7FF78E827F46453A9E5FE9520341C741.description: After using the toilet or helping a child use the toilet

B23B8FE8510B453DA423D4BE783AD8E5.description: Before and after eating meals and snacks or feeding a child

A972838F7AA8473CB5061561A9A48E93.description: Before handling or preparing food or bottles

EE345CBB20EA41EFA0088C54038B4C0A.description: Rinse hands and dry with a single-use towel.

487E262118ED4AD0B6A03E255085E747.description: Rub hands for at least 20 seconds including back of hands, between fingers and under fingernails.

66EE64995F7D46049270E074FE52BB39.description: Use liquid soap and rub hands together to create a soapy lather.

C055AFA8ED37453B83E3E2241B1AE7F5.description: Use warm water. Run water over hands to remove soil before applying soap.

BA90B90FCB954FA0806F2FBCDCEC1643.description: Proper Handwashing Procedures should be posted and followed:

EF69E6D89FF54F878C608E11DEC410B4.description: Toys and materials (bedding, dress-up clothing, etc.) should be cleaned weekly or more often if needed. (ie: for example if a toy is in a child’s mouth)

5623254B0570467D9296F7F50A22ABA2.description: Keeping the facility clean, sanitized, and washing hands are key factors in preventing and reducing the spread of illness

842DF48C015C4148AEC2A16757F8216A.description: Parents will receive a written report of every incident, accident, or injury involving the child

907E961787D84176930201D4B1F7A1D9.description: Health and safety plan are located in the center and followed in an emergency or disaster

02C3757A3C0543DFA3F362AD824CB585.description: Fire drills are conducted monthly and disaster drills at least once every 6 months

0556EF42DB8245D9AD3094ADF59037CD.description: Keep first-aid supplies in center, including at least antiseptic, bandages and tweezers

2BE0BD4FC8E74FE5972DF491C90F307C.description: Items with small parts or that fit through a paper towel tube are too small for children under the age of 2

C2B174F1D6BC4EC894801D67072BEE11.description: Objects and other items that are brought into the center (backpacks, things in pockets, etc.) may also be hazardous

DB73A6F410064881908911ADA98B05B6.description: All harmful objects and hazards are inaccessible to children; to view a list see the Child Care Center Rule Interpretation Manual, section 13

B14130DE6F844FDDAD684E7D4B68BB77.description: Engage and Reflect- staff work together to assist in the care of children

8BAE1C0524924ECCBA2122037FF4F5C5.description: Anticipate Children’s Behavior- staff use what they know about their children to anticipate potential challenges

1C7D4215BE0147CC9D3A067584E27113.description: Listen- listen for specific sounds or the absence of them that could indicate a potential danger

5BDBA521823B432CA48D4ADEEA738995.description: Scan and Count- staff always know how many children are in their care and what they are doing

F6F77B6404FB4FC387E24199DEA20A76.description: Position Staff- If there is more than one staff member in a space, position yourselves so that you can observe and see children at all times

3F60A01297514B20819F53281E1C500D.description: Set Up the Environment- so staff can supervise and be accessible to children at all times

92B5858CA78B42A0AE638D8E0167BBEE.description: Apply active supervision of each child at all times.

325966CD64BA41D8AD727E6F313E6ED5.description: Maintain the number of caregiver-to-child ratios for single-age groups of children in the table below:

75B8B0A4329B4697B471090A411F22F0.description: Identify qualifications for directors, lead teachers, and supporting teachers in an early childhood setting.

381A924D6F4D473C83CF9270FE291B97.description: Students will review and implement Utah licensing standards.

5A5D5B375C0A49E79CB28B057A04A69C.description: Training should be provided based on individual center or preschool rules

85835B85E4864F119D4F152416066BAD.description: Individual center health and safety plan based on Utah Childcare Licensing Rules

38A3D4FE58E34C1DA869188AAED14B86.description: 2.5 hours of training is required before providing care to children

5B31D8A941464724A21BE14181CA141D.description: Utah preservice-All students should complete the annual Utah preservice training

D8E54DEBC3F2453BBCE75BD95CF953AD.description: Students will receive Utah Pre-service Training and implement Utah Child Care Licensing Rules
